title: MGFI-Net: A Multi-Grained Feature Integration Network for Enhanced Medical Image Segmentation
author: Yucheng Zeng (Shanghai University), ..., Yucheng Zeng (Shanghai University)
relevance_why: The paper tackles a crucial aspect of image segmentation, which could inspire improvements in audio signal segmentation techniques, particularly in handling noise and complex structures.
background: Medical image segmentation involves classifying each pixel in medical images into different regions, which poses challenges due to noise, low contrast, or complex anatomical structures.
contribution: This paper introduces MGFI-Net to solve the challenges in medical image segmentation, achieving superior accuracy and time efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggled with combining local features with broader contextual information and preserving edge details in segmentation tasks.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing models by integrating multi-grained feature extraction with an edge enhancement module, which dynamically adjusts convolutional kernels for effective edge retention.

key_innovation: The combination of a Multi-Grained Feature Integration Module and an Adaptive Edge Module that dynamically preserves edge details while enhancing segmentation accuracy in complex images.
real_world_impact: The advancements in segmentation accuracy and efficiency have the potential to improve clinical applications, leading to better diagnosis and treatment in medical settings.
limitations: No specific limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Multi-Grained Feature Integration Networ: **MGFI-Net** is a proposed deep learning architecture designed for enhanced segmentation of medical images by integrating multi-scale features and improving edge detail preservation.
new_terms.Adaptive Edge (AE) module: **Adaptive Edge module** refers to a component of the MGFI-Net that utilizes adaptive convolutions to preserve complex edge structures in segmentation tasks.
